urn:contentItem:5WS6-C4W1-JBGS-H22P-00000-00InsurTech taps premium growth potential in emerging markets2019-03-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:07ZLexisNexisInsurTech taps premium growth potential in emerging markets

 

Two of the biggest trends in global insurance in recent years are premium growth in emerging markets and the rising importance of technology across the supply chain. The latter has come to be referred to as InsurTech, a potentially disruptive trend that heralds both threats to and opportunities for incumbents and newcomers alike. While technological solutions are being applied along the length of the insurance supply chain in advanced markets, their focus in emerging markets has primarily been on driving premium growth. Stronger growth in emerging and developing economies since the turn of the century has given rise to a swelling middle class. At the same time, many lower and some middle-income countries have managed to largely skip the mass rollout of fixed-line telephony as the prevalence of low-cost mobile telephony has seen a surge in mobile phone penetration rates not too dissimilar to those in advanced economies.

In turn, this has facilitated financial inclusion, allowing tens of millions to access formal financial services for the first time. Kenya's mobile money system, M-Pesa, is a notable example, blazing a trail for mobile banking in developing economies. In fact, Kenya's mobile payment system is on par with, or even ahead of, those in many advanced economies. Over time, the sophistication and availability of digital financial services has greatly expanded, from e-payments to microcredits and, more recently, insurance products.

Insurtech

According to a report titled "Technology and innovation in the insurance sector" published in 2017 by the OECD, InsurTech is used to describe "the new technologies with the potential to bring innovation to the insurance sector and impact the regulatory practices of insurance markets". InsurTech, as compared to financial technology (fintech), is more often related to service improvements for individuals, as opposed to businesses. Sector participants sometimes use the term more broadly to encompass the application of digital technology to all stages of the insurance supply chain. In its insurance market outlook for 2018-19, global insurer Munich Re noted that "InsurTech start-ups benefit from the achievements of fintech companies, as new financial technologies also allow insurers' product ranges to be expanded, alternative sales channels to be created and additional groups of clients to be reached". This is highlighted as being particularly relevant in "underdeveloped insurance markets by offering simple, innovative and needs-based products digitally, and thereby developing new markets". Concrete examples cited in the Munich Re article include micro-insurance for health and crop insurance, which can be contracted and managed via mobile phone.

Penetration

The share of insurance premiums in GDP is closely and positively correlated with GDP per capita, and varies significantly across regions. According to the "World insurance in 2017: solid, but mature life markets weigh on growth" report by Sigma, Swiss Re's research and analysis arm, North America and Europe had the highest insurance penetration rates that year, measured as premiums as a percentage of GDP, with 7.1% and 6.5% of GDP, respectively. Asia, which includes the Middle East, and Oceania tied in third place with 5.6%. While Taiwan (21.3%), Hong Kong (17.9%), South Korea (11.6%), Japan (8.6%) and Singapore (8.2%) recorded rates above those seen in North America, about half of the countries in Asia have rates less than 3% of GDP, with large, populous economies such as Pakistan and Bangladesh registering rates under 1%. Latin America and the Caribbean and Africa hold the most potential for catch-up growth, with penetration rates of 3.06% and 2.96%, respectively.

Premium Growth

The pattern in premium growth, however, is somewhat different, reflecting both stronger growth in emerging markets and the catch-up potential represented by relatively low penetration rates. In 2017 premiums were flat in North America, and contracted in Europe and Oceania by 0.5% and 6.2%, respectively. Meanwhile, premium growth in Asia registered 5.7%, but differed markedly between its sub-segments. Advanced Asian economies contracted by 1.1%, while emerging Asian markets and the Middle East and Central Asia region grew by 14.7% and 5%, respectively. Premium growth in Latin America and the Caribbean was a modest 0.1%, reflecting muted economic activity across the region, particularly in Venezuela, Argentina and Brazil. Similarly, premium growth in Africa was weak, at 0.5%, dragged down by the performance of South Africa, which dominates the continent's insurance market, and Nigeria, which experienced an economic blowback from weak oil prices.

Mobile Phones

Mobile phone penetration is almost universal in advanced countries, and rapidly catching up in emerging and developing economies. According to the World Bank, in 2017 there were more than 115 mobile phone subscriptions per 100 people in North America, Europe, and the East Asia and Pacific region, while there were more than 100 in the Middle East and North Africa and Latin America and the Caribbean regions. Even in sub-Saharan Africa, there were more than 70 mobile phone users per 100 people.

A similar pattern can be found in the use of mobile banking services, albeit at much lower levels. According to the World Bank's 2017 Global Findex database, the share of the adult population that used a mobile phone or the internet to access a financial institution account in the past year was 68% in North America, 36% in Europe and Central Asia, 32% in the East Asia and Pacific region, 12% in the Middle East and North Africa region, 10% in Latin America and the Caribbean, and 8% in sub-Saharan Africa. Although not surveyed specifically, it could be expected that the penetration of digital insurance products would be an order of magnitude smaller across all regions. Moreover, the extent of mobile phone penetration relative to that of the use of mobile banking underlines the potential for growth in the coming years. For bancassurers in particular, this provides significant opportunities to cross-sell insurance products, while for pure insurers there is potential for joint ventures with banks and technology - notably e-payment - companies.

Key Figures

As for the InsurTech segment itself, CB Insights, a tech market intelligence platform, estimated that total global investment reached $2.3bn in 2017 following a compound annual growth rate of 45% since 2012. In the first half of 2018 there were $1.3bn worth of InsurTech deals, putting the year in a good position to top the annual record of $2.7bn in 2015. The bulk of InsurTech deals since 2013 have been made in developed markets, with the US alone accounting for 58% that year. While leading emerging markets, such as China and India only recorded shares of 5% and 4%, respectively, they are beginning to make their presence felt. Emerging markets share of global InsurTech deals is increasing, with China and India accounting for 13% and 10%, respectively, in the second quarter of 2018. Meanwhile, Israel accounted for 6% and South Africa for 4%. While new, sometimes disruptive, market entrants are starting to account for a larger share of sales, 83% of those made between 2012 and 2017 involved an established insurer or reinsurer as a sole or joint investor.

Big Tech

Even if much of InsurTech investment has thus far been complementary, rather than disruptive, to incumbent insurers, large technology companies are entering the market, particularly in economies such as China. For example, Alibaba, sometimes labelled as the Chinese Amazon, teamed up with Tencent, another Chinese technology giant, and insurer Ping An Insurance to launch China's first wholly online insurer, Zhong An, in 2013. Over time, it is likely that the biggest global tech firms will look to enter insurance markets in other advanced and emerging economies, either through their own well-established brands or through joint ventures with established insurers. An August 2018 survey by US-based marketing research company JD Power found that one in five US consumers would be willing to purchase home insurance from Amazon or Google.

Emerging Asia

Given the size and growth rate of its economy and its even faster expanding insurance sector, it is hardly surprising that China is not only the top emerging market contributor to global premium growth, but has been a key driver of overall global premium growth in recent years in light of a relatively lacklustre performance in many advanced economies. In 2017 Chinese insurance premiums adjusted for inflation grew by 16.2% to reach a 4.1% share of GDP. According to Swiss Re, "China will remain the biggest contributor to global insurance market growth among emerging markets for the next decade at least". However, given the extent of convergence with the insurance penetration rate in more advanced economies by 2030, the increase in Chinese premiums is expected to moderate thereafter, with other emerging markets taking up the mantle to drive the expansion of global premiums.

Beyond China, the extent of InsurTech's impact varies. Kheedhej Anansiriprapha, executive director at Thai General Insurance Association, told OBG that "online insurance sales account for a relatively small proportion of the market, with only motor and travel products being purchased online. Finally, it will be important for products to become tailored to specific markets to help overcome persistent cultural resistance to using formal financial services.

urn:contentItem:5S7T-D7X1-JC13-H2K8-00000-00Integrating Blockchain Technology To Source Lithium Ion Battery Supply2018-05-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:07ZLexisNexisIntegrating Blockchain Technology To Source Lithium Ion Battery Supply

AMERICAN MANGANESE INC("AMY-V;AMYZF-0") - Integrating Blockchain Technology To Source Lithium Ion Battery - Supply

Larry W. Reaugh, President and Chief Executive Officer of American Manganese Inc.("American Manganese" or "AMY" or the "Company") is pleased to announce that the Company is working with Circulor Ltd. ("Circulor") of London, England, to pilot blockchain technology in order to create a traceable and ethically sourced circular economy for electric vehicle (EV) battery metals, such as cobalt.

American Manganese Inc.CEO, Larry Reaugh says, "AMY and Circulor will be mapping the lifecycle of an EV battery and understanding the value flow through the production process and lifecycle. As well as providing a road map for AMY to source valuable lithium ion batteries."

The blockchain technology will create traceability of EV battery metals from the mine through their first use and then as they are recycled.

Circulor Ltd. CEO, Doug Johnson-Poensgen, said "Blockchain technology has the potential to transform complex industrial supply chains both by assuring provenance and improving efficiency. This joint project will create the first blockchain solution designed specifically for the EV circular economy."

AMY and Circulor will engage other industrial partners involved in the EV battery lifecycle, including car manufacturers, during the pilot.

As reference to the existing supply chain's ethical concerns for battery metals, click the following link to read the CNN article: 'Carmakers and big tech struggle to keep batteries free from child labor'. http://money.cnn.com/2018/05/01/technology/cobalt-congo-child-labor-car-sma rtphone-batteries/index.html

About Circulor Ltd.

Circulor Ltd. is a London (UK) based blockchain start-up focused on materials provenance in the Electric Vehicle supply chain.

Circulor are creating distributed applications to help supply chain participants prove provenance, improve supply chain transparency and reduce counterparty risk exposure. The data pool that will be created in a blockchain ecosystem will eventually allow participants to unlock value well beyond what is currently possible, without compromising commercial confidentiality or violating antitrust/anti-competitive regulations.

The company has been engaging with a range of supply chain participants from car manufacturers to specialists in ethical and sustainable sourcing to prove the utility of blockchain technology and ensure that its solutions can integrate with existing supply chain management solutions.

Circulor is privately held.

About American Manganese Inc.

American Manganese Inc.is a diversified specialty and critical metal company focused on capitalizing on its patented intellectual property through low cost production or recovery of electrolytic manganese products throughout the world, and recycling of spent electric vehicle lithium ion rechargeable batteries.

Interest in the Company's patented process has adjusted the focus of American Manganese Inc.toward the examination of applying its patented technology for other purposes and materials. American Manganese Inc.aims to capitalize on its patented technology and proprietary know-how to become the industry leader in recycling spent electric vehicle lithium ion batteries and recovering 100% of the cathode metals such as: Lithium-Cobalt, Lithium-Cobalt-Nickel-Manganese, Lithium-Cobalt- Aluminum and Lithium-Manganese (Please see the Company's March 27, 2018 Company's Business Plan ("CBP") for further details).

On behalf of Management

AMERICAN MANGANESE INC.

Larry W. Reaugh

President and Chief Executive Officer

Feb 02, 2015( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Moving deeper into the Internet of Things, Intelhas acquired smarthome startup Lantiq. The move will accelerate Lantiq's smart home gateway and intelligent access networks business.

It will also help the world's biggest chip maker advance its position in the Internet of Things, or making everyday objects smart and connected. Intelsaid that the move will help its offering in cable residential gateways as well as gateways for digital subscriber lines (DSL) over phone networks, fiber, long-term evolution (LTE), and Internet of Things smart routers. The move could also help Intelbecome more competitive against arch rival Qualcomm, which announced its own smarthome initiative [1]at the 2015 International CES. Big companies like Intel, Samsung, Qualcomm, Broadcom and many others are all jockeying to become the center of digital ecosystems[2] that drive smarthomes and the larger Internet of Things 'By 2018, we expect more than 800 million broadband connected households worldwide,' said Kirk Skaugen, senior vice president and general manager of Intel's Client Computing Group, in a statement. 'Intelhas been a global leader in driving broadband into the home and to connected compute devices. The combination of our cable gateway business with Lantiq's technology and talent can allow global service providers to introduce new home computing experiences and enable consumers to take advantage of a more smart and connected home.' The deal is subject to regulatory approvals. Terms were not disclosed. 'Inteland Lantiq share a common vision about the evolution of the connected home and the intelligent network,' said Dan Artusi, CEO of Munich, Germany-based Lantiq, in a statement. 'Together we can drive the transformation of the broadband customer premises equipment (CPE) as it becomes a smart gateway that connects an increasingly diverse roster of devices and services in the home.' Lantiq's main investor was San Francisco-based Golden Gate Capital. Lantiq said it has over 2,000 patents related to broadband communications and offers technologies including xDSL solutions with vectoring and G.Fast; fiber-based technologies such as fiber to the distribution point (FTTdp) and other technologies. urn:contentItem:5DTW-3381-F08V-607X-00000-00Intel joins foes of ‘net neutrality’2014-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:07ZLexisNexisCPg. 03Intel joins foes of ‘net neutrality’ Mike Rogoway | mrogoway@oregonian.comThe Oregonian

Intel and other big tech companies have come out against a proposal to reclassify Internet service as a Title II public utility subject to regulation, a position that puts the company at odds with President Barack Obama, U.S. Sen. Ron Wyden, Netflix and the city of Portland.

Many Internet activists have urged the Federal Communications Commission to reclassify the Internet to ensure “net neutrality,” the principle that all Web traffic be treated equally. Netflix and others warn that without those protections, online services will have to pay a premium for speedy access to customers.

In a letter Wednesday to congressional leaders, Intel, Qualcomm, IBM and 50 other members of the Telecommunications Industry Association — primarily hardware-oriented companies — warn that such regulation would deter broadband expansion in the U.S.

“Reversing course now by shifting to Title II means that instead of billions of broadband investment driving other sectors of the economy forward, any reduction in this spending will stifle growth across the entire economy,” the companies wrote.

Obama came out forcefully in favor of Title II reclassification last month, a position long advocated by Wyden. Portland Mayor Charlie Hales sent a letter to the FCC last summer taking the same position.

U.S. Rep. Greg Walden, however, is a fierce Title II opponent, arguing that it threatens the success of the existing Internet economy.

A decision from the FCC is due next year.

urn:contentItem:5HKR-RGH1-JB3N-T51K-00000-00Intelligence agencies are using terrorism as a lever to weaken online privacy2015-12-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:07ZLexisNexisTECH NEWSIntelligence agencies are using terrorism as a lever to weaken online privacyAmulya Gopalakrishnan

Perhaps predictably, the battle against ISIS is blurring into a battle against encryption -- the encoding and scram bling of digital messages so that they can only be read by those who have the right keys. A showdown is on in the US, with security agencies demonizing these privacy-protecting technologies and demanding a "backdoor" to them, while tech companies resist this logic.

UK Prime Minister David Cameron has argued that there should be "no form of communication...that we cannot read." Meanwhile, there were rumours (now busted) of France banning the widely used ToR (the onion router), which anonymizes users by hiding the original IP address and routing traffic through several points.

End-to-end encryption became popular after Edward Snowden's leaks about widespread spying by the US National Security Agency. This means that data gets encrypted on one device and decrypted only when it reaches the recipient, making it technically impossible for anyone in the middle to access it. Most big tech companies have tightened their default encryption since. There is a set of new messaging tools, like Signal, CryptoCat and others, which allows users to mutually verify their keys.

"People are far more security-aware now -not just about protecting their information from the government, but also hackers and malicious third parties," says Raman Jit Singh Chima, global policy director at Access Now, a digital freedom group that successfully petitioned the Obama administration to take a more considered view.

Intelligence agencies claim that these technologies give terrorists an invisibility cloak. "But terrorists aren't looking for government-approved platforms to communicate, they'll just find other black market tech," says Chinmayi Arun, research director of the Centre for Communication Governance.

"In the process, citizens will get worse encryption, journalists won't be able to communicate securely with their sources. Intelligence agencies create this false confrontation between national security and personal security," says tech analyst Nikhil Pahwa. He argues that the link between encryption and intelligence failure is a smokescreen; the real problem, as witnessed in the Paris attacks, is that security agencies are unable to sift the signal from the noise despite the data they do have.

Others, like security consultant Akash Mahajan, argue that forcing tech companies to build a backdoor would create vulnerability -one that could also be used by others for malign ends. "Encryption is math. Math doesn't care if you're the NSA or Daesh," says Mishi Choudhary of the Software Freedom Law Centre.

"Terrorism isn't the only fact in the world. These tools are used by businesses everywhere, weakening encryption could make corporate espionage much easier," says Mahajan. India has stakes in this global official backlash against encryption. "Indian banks and companies, the Paytms and Flipkarts, are the first to suffer with weak encryption," Choudhary points out.

India has several laws, ranging from the Indian Telegraph Act to the Information Technology Act, which let central and state governments monitor private communications in the name of security or public safety. Service providers have to agree that they will open their networks to government surveillance; interception and monitoring systems exist across a range of intelligence and tax agencies. There is no judicial oversight, getting metadata is not even seen as interception.

The core problem is that "there is no comprehensive data protection law in India, apart from scattered requirements under different statutes," says lawyer Shyam Divan.

The government's draft encryption policy, unveiled in September, was booed off stage because it sought to weaken standards rather than boost them. It had heavy-handed specifications on encryption algorithms, mandatory registration of encryption products, and the retention of unencrypted user information for 90 days.

Now, as the government reworks its stand on encryption, the question is which way it will respond to the global climate of opinion. "It should learn from the mistakes of other countries, where overbroad regulation took years to fix. Undermining security standards just leaves everyone vulnerable," sums up Chima.

urn:contentItem:5WKW-4CK1-JDVW-N25P-00000-00Interest in AT&T's RSNs may be constrained by regulation, rights renewals2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:07ZLexisNexisExclusiveInterest in AT&T's RSNs may be constrained by regulation, rights renewalsMike Reynolds

As AT&T looks for more assets to sell to pay down its debt, media experts say the company's regional sports networks could fetch a hefty price tag, but finding the right buyer may be difficult.

As AT&T Inc. looks for more assets to sell to pay down its debt, media experts say the company's regional sports networks could fetch a hefty price tag, but finding the right buyer may be difficult.

While experts say the two most logical buyers would be Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. which will soon rank as the largest holder of regional sports networks in the U.S. and Comcast Corp.'s NBC Sports Regional Networks, they note that those companies' leading positions in the sports programming market are likely to draw heightened regulatory scrutiny for any future sports network buys.

AT&T is reportedly considering the sale of networks AT&T SportsNet Pittsburgh (US), AT&T SportsNet Rocky Mountain (US), AT&T SportsNet Southwest (US) and ROOT SPORTS Northwest (US) as it looks to raise additional funds to lower its total debt, which was $196.44 billion as of the end of the first quarter. Executives previously said the company planned to pursue $6 billion to $8 billion of asset sales in 2019. In May, AT&T CFO John Stephens said the company had already raised about $5 billion of its goal. According to media reports, the four AT&T RSNs could fetch some $1 billion.

A FOX Sports camera films from the sidelines of a baseball game.Sinclair Broadcast is set to become the largest owner of regionalsports networks in the U.S. after it closes on a portfolio of FOXnetworks.Source: Associated Press

Sinclair is awaiting the closing of a $9.6 billion deal to purchase 21 former FOX RSNs from Walt Disney Co. The FOX networks went up for sale as a condition of the U.S. Department of Justice approving Disney's purchase of myriad assets from 21st Century Fox Inc. The deal will make Sinclair the top RSN operator in the U.S. NBC Sports Regional Networks will rank second with seven RSNs.

"Strategically, it would make sense for [Sinclair] to digest the purchase and get a rhythm going with their new assets," said Curt Pires, president of consultancy CAP Sports. The Disney-Sinclair deal still needs to gain DOJ approval. "Why make that process more difficult right now?" Pires said.

Last month, three Democratic presidential hopefuls asked the DOJ and U.S. Federal Communications Commission to take a look at how the pending Sinclair deal could impact network carriage pricing and Sinclair's overall reach given that it would bring together the sports network portfolio with Sinclair's extensive local U.S. broadcast station holdings.

Sinclair, which did not respond to a request for comment, expects the deal to close in the third quarter.

Mark Lazarus, chairman of NBCUniversal Broadcast, Cable, Sports and News, previously indicated the company had concerns about the regulatory scrutiny that NBCU might draw with for some potential regional sports network buys.

At an industry conference in December 2018, Lazarus said that NBCU did not have serious interest in the FOX RSNs in particular because it was unlikely any deals for the assets within Comcast's footprint would pass regulatory muster. The potential for vertical integration of the RSNs in markets where NBC (US) also owns stations and Comcast is a major cable operator has informed the company's strategy, he said.

The markets served by the AT&T RSNs fall within Comcast's video footprint, and while NBC does not own stations in the AT&T RSN markets, NBCUniversal Media LLC's Telemundo (US) does.

CAP Sports' Pires said he is not sure NBCU would have interest in AT&T Sports Southwest, given its involvement in the now-defunct CSN Houston, the predecessor to the AT&T's current Houston-based RSN, which was forced into Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 2014 and later sold to AT&T and DIRECTV.

NBC declined to comment.

Another factor likely to influence buyer interest in AT&T's RSNs is that a number of team rights renewals are in the offing, meaning any network buyer would soon be renegotiating what it must pay for programming distribution rights. In discussing the upside of the deal for the FOX RSNs, Sinclair said the portfolio as a whole carries an 11-year weighted average for the expiration of rights deals, giving it a measure of cost certainty.

Outside of Sinclair and NBCU, media experts said other potential buyers could be found among the parties that had expressed interest in the FOX RSNs to be sold to Sinclair. Among the final bidders for those networks were John Malone's Liberty Media Corp. in conjunction with Major League Baseball Enterprises Inc. and Big 3. Private equity and big tech companies were also reported to be interested, though some were reported to have concerns about the expense of maintaining sports programming rights.

While tech companies like Amazon could be interested, Lee Berke, president and CEO of media consultancy LHB Sports, Entertainment & Media Inc., said he believes it will take five to 10 years for the streaming market to grow to include wide-scale, OTT streaming packages that would host networks of regional interest.

Nevertheless, Berke believes there will be interest in the live programming that sports networks deliver. "The content remains very valuable," he said.

UK Finance issued the following news release:

Policymakers and regulators worldwide should help shape an orderly modernisation and digitisation of the financial sector to address the opportunities and risks associated with big techs' increasing role in financial services according to a new report by the International Banking Federation (IBFed) and global management consulting firm Oliver Wyman.

The report makes three distinct sets of recommendations: revising measures within financial regulation, strengthening the policy response on themes that cut across industries, and extending finance-specific regulations to other industries where inconsistencies in regulation and enforcement have emerged.

Hannah Gurga, Managing Director, Digital Technology & Cyber, UK Finance, said:

"Technology is transforming many aspects of our lives, including the way we choose to bank and manage our finances. Across the banking and finance sector, firms are investing in new technologies and partnering with fintech operators to develop products and services that better meet the needs of their customers. The entry of big tech into financial services creates new opportunities, but it also brings new risks. As we embark on this next market evolution, consideration is now needed as to how best to maintain the stability, resilience, and consumer protections that are so integral to the banking system."

urn:contentItem:5G1R-1KV1-JB20-G2NG-00000-00International Business Machines Corp at JPMorgan Global Technology, Media and Telecom Conference - Final2015-05-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:07ZLexisNexis051815a5715252.752International Business Machines Corp at JPMorgan Global Technology, Media and Telecom Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Steve Mills

IBM Corporation - EVP, Software & Systems

Conference Call Participants

* Tien-tsin Huang

JPMorgan - Analyst

Presentation

TIEN-TSIN HUANG, ANALYST, JPMORGAN: All right. Thanks, everyone, for joining. Once again, my name is Tien-tsin Huang; I cover the computer services and IT consulting group at JPMorgan. So next up to bat we have IBM. From IBM we have Steve Mills, he is the -- he runs software and systems as well, to give us an update.

So again, I am going to do fireside chat as a format. We will take questions from the Ask a Question portal. So feel free to ask questions there. And I was asked to remind everyone if you want to tweet about the conference, #TMTBoston, if you care to do that, if not no big deal. I won't be doing that for sure. But anyway, thanks again, Steve, for being here. Steve has been a -- what is it, a 40-plus year vet at IBM?

STEVE MILLS, EVP, SOFTWARE & SYSTEMS, IBM CORPORATION: 42.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: So you have seen a lot of things happen at IBM. So very lucky to pick his brain a little bit here. But I thought we'd start out with just sort of the obligatory question, Steve, if you wouldn't mind just -- this is a tech conference. Maybe if you could just walk us around the globe here and tell us what you are hearing from CIOs, CTOs, CEOs, etc. What is selling, what is not and just generally how demand is across the globe and then we can dig in deeper from there if that is okay.

Questions and Answers

STEVE MILLS: Okay. Well, first of all I would say that the patterns that we see around the world are somewhat more industry specific than geographic. There are differences and the US market I think is a little bit more active and energetic than the European market. Emerging markets still obviously represent strong growth rates albeit not as high as they had once been. More importantly are the similarities you see at the industry level.

So financial services companies are always a tale of two cities. On one side they are trying to improve operational efficiency, that is where they spend a huge amount of their IT budget in their back-office operations. But everyone is trying to free up money to get into new types of customer service, analytics, obviously have to serve the mobile client. And clearly a lot of money going into various aspects of security, counter fraud, any money laundering, those kinds of spaces.

Retailers are I think in kind of refresh mode. I think retailers recognize that in order to maintain relevancy they are going to have to do more around leveraging customer relationships, loyalty programs are hot. Ship from store, Amazon has sort of thrown down the gauntlet in certain markets about next day shipping and even same-day shipping. So retailers are rethinking their distribution models using stores not just as walk in but also stores as distribution centers. So there is a lot going on there.

Healthcare space, you have seen IBM increase our level of investment in healthcare. We are very excited about what we see as a shift that has occurred in the last few years, particularly among healthcare providers where they are looking seriously at information technology investments as now being on a par with the kinds of investments historically they made in hospital equipment.

IT and information-based healthcare, information-based healthcare delivery is becoming an ever bigger topic out there and that market obviously is moving pretty well at this point in time and moving in that direction.

I think other industries tend to have their classical cyclical characteristics, manufacturing sort of depends upon what particular cycle you are going through and obviously a lot of that is long-term capital investment and clearly leveraging of technology. But in ways somewhat different than you might see in some of the more, if you will, virtual businesses that are really based upon information technology.

Internet of Things is a hot topic in the marketplace today. Anybody who is managing or maintaining expensive capital infrastructure is looking for better predictive maintenance, the ability to manage, maintain and ensure the uptime of their equipment, there is real money tied up in that. We see projects that have just extraordinary returns in the IoT space for a relatively modest initial investment being driven entirely by predictive maintenance cycles.

And so, these are all hot spaces in terms of an industry perspective. I think you turn it on its side and people are spending money on analytics in just about every dimension and domain, analytics, analytics, analytics. Mobile device and digital engagement -- [I think more] the device is a piece of it, but there is a very important part of it related to digital engagement, how do I engage with my customers.

I think people have this notion in their head that there is an Uber-izing application that they potentially can hunt out for their business that gives them distinct client value and therefore growth opportunities. So that is a hot topic. The whole world is spending a fortune on security. That is probably not going to come to an end.

The byproduct of this incredible porous telecommunications infrastructure that we have created that allows commerce to exist on a global scale and also that it is ripe for the malicious and ripe for those that want to attack those kinds of scenarios. And so, everybody is spending more and more and more money, if you will, on their defensive measures and posture related to analytics.

And of course the last thing is, not to leave it out, but cloud. Cloud touches everything; everyone talks about cloud in just about every context one can imagine. It continues to be a somewhat confusing topic insofar as you have to qualify and clarify exactly what aspect of cloud-based deployment and cloud-based services you are looking for in your particular business and your profile.

I think in general there is a characteristic of move to cloud that spans at one end of the spectrum more human interaction where these things are very popular cloud solutions. And at the other end extreme data intensity and data quantity where the cost of moving data and concerns about privacy and security are clearly having an effect on the rate and pace of adoption.

But there is no question that we are seeing a pretty big move towards cloud-related services, especially for those things that involve people interacting with people.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Anything to say that is helpful on the vertical side and going through some of the themes? Anything to say or add geographically in terms of what you are seeing?

STEVE MILLS: Again, I think that China, which obviously carries enormous expectation for the future, I don't think those expectations have diminished in any way. I think how that is going to evolve and come about looking ahead over the next decade is going to be a little bit different than what we've seen over the last couple of decades.

And obviously China has a very big push on local company participation. We have certainly been moving our business model increasingly towards a partnering model in China. We know that in many market spaces we're going to have to go to market with partners to an even greater degree than we have gone to market with partners in the past. So that is certainly a part of the shift in China.

But I don't think China is necessarily unique. I mean, you see some of these same issues emerging in Europe, a desire to ensure participation of local companies. Everybody wants to be a part of information technology and where it is going. It is the transforming technology of the last 60 years. It will be in the transforming technology of the next century. And every government sees this as representing opportunity for economic growth.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Okay, so maybe let's shift and talk about more IBM specifically in terms of the investments. I know there is a lot of change given all the big tech waves that you just described. So just maybe talk about where you are placing your bets organically. I know Watson has been something I'm sure we will talk about as well. But also inorganically with Software. So, can you up us understand the difference between the two there, organic versus inorganic investments?

STEVE MILLS: Well, let's just back up a second. So, and I think we have been pretty clear in our quarterly calls and annual analyst sessions that we have been investing in technologies that represent the faster rate of growth in the industry and therefore bringing about more transformation. So cloud analytics, mobile, social security -- these spaces are among the faster growing for our business.

We have pegged the 20% on average rate of growth. We have certainly been experiencing that or better in those market spaces. That now represents more than 25% of IBM in 2014. And we clearly would expect that that rate of growth is going to be an ever bigger percentage of the Company.

That doesn't mean that traditional uses of technology disappear. But where the growth is going to be. And the fact of the matter is how many of those traditional spaces will transform are going to be affected by cloud analytics, mobile, social, security and so on.

So, as we've seen so many times before, each sort of new wave of technology or technology shift has both the ability to pull the industry in a particular direction, but it also washes back across the rest of what is there.

And things that remain, and so much of what we have created over the decades in technology still remains, but it is there because it was able to adapt to the changing dynamics of the way people wanted to access and use the technology, not that it just remains sort of in place.

I think this notion of legacy sometimes is a bit of an illusion insofar as even things that people would deem as legacy actually go through some pretty dramatic changes.

So we are, as we have been forever at IBM, shifting our Company, shifting the mix, changing the underlying profile of the business and moving towards where we see the value going. We are a Company grounded on invention. And so, we view that there is a profit margin to be had around IP and invention, we are very much geared towards that.

Because we generate good free cash flow we also buy things. So there is the inorganic side of the model. But the inorganic side has to fit with the organic side. To get a return on that invested capital you have got to be acquiring things that fit with what you have, so good adjacency, good synergy and therefore you get a lift.

The acquired company, the acquired assets, we could actually get them to grow faster and become bigger because they that fit well with what IBM already has. And we often get synergistic effects going the other way, which is something we acquired now completes a solution, makes it more desirable to the customer and they will buy more of what we currently have.

So we are sticking with that model, it has worked very well for us. Over the last decade plus, 15 years, we've bought 150 companies. And so, we continue to be acquisitive. But at the end of the day we are going to clearly do more -- at a $6-billion-plus R&D there is more organic development going on than inorganic.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Yes. So, you mentioned IP research, I know IBM research obviously is always leading the way in a lot of new and fun areas and cognitive is one. And we still get a lot of questions around Watson. I know Watson Health is something that has been getting a little bit of airtime with the press.

Can you just talk about Watson Health and how you plan to monetize that, just the business model there? And can we see something similar come about in other industries?

STEVE MILLS: So healthcare-related projects, we embarked on those fairly early after we did the Jeopardy game and demonstrated what this technology can do. And Watson is a system, it is a collection of technologies. It was derived from a whole set of research initiatives and product initiatives in IBM.

And we were looking for a particular pattern, if you will, that brought many technologies together. In context understanding, be able to parse and understand text-based information, surfacing ontology's and relationships, and then putting to work some fairly unique AI capability that IBM had inside in a set of use cases that would make some business sense.

And so, playing Jeopardy was a [stalking] horse for the research team to get excited about bringing all these things together. But you saw us immediately shift into healthcare examples. As soon as we finished that effort in 2011, played the game, we were quickly into -- and here is how this technology now can be applied, healthcare is an ideal environment to do it.

Where an inferencing-based model is most effective is where you have massive quantities of data, far more than any human being could ever read and understand, where relationships will vary as a function of the characteristics.

So we think about healthcare, which we all understand a little bit about. We think about symptomatic information leading to diagnosis, leading to treatment, leading to outcome. And as any physician will tell you, vary the symptoms you vary the diagnosis. Can I see all the patterns as a physician. Why do physicians consult with each other? Well, because no one physician can know everything.

When you have literally tens of millions of scientific documents being published related to healthcare on an annual basis there is no way to keep up with that, even in your own specialty it is hard to do. So why not use the computer as the basis of assembling all of that data and then go further, let it find patterns, relationships and associations and point you to the possibility of a diagnosis or a treatment that you hadn't seen before because there was no way to actually understand all the data.

To do the what if -- maybe I should run another test or maybe I shouldn't. Will more testing lead to more information of value or will it just lead to more cost? I think physicians in general want to get it right the first time. And so, we are excited about this technology is ideally suited to the medical challenge.

We've just done a couple of acquisitions, we've bought a couple companies that have given us the statistical data now on 100 million lives. So that data is important because it provides us with diagnosis, provides us with treatment and outcome information for 100 million human lives.

That provides a strong statistical base and we are finding that providers that have their own data are willing to share that data with us, particularly when we are showing them patterns in our [100 million] that they weren't seeing in their data. And if we add their data to ours that 100 million goes up. Our notion is, well let's double it in double it and double it again.

It is not that IBM needs to even own all the data, it is access to the data because the insights are where the value is. That doesn't make us a healthcare provider, it makes us a Company that supports the insight challenge related to figuring out what the right diagnosis and the right treatment is.

Clearly accuracy is important to all of us, but bringing down cost is also important. And the healthcare industry is ready to make these kinds of moves. So we are quite excited about this. It is an ideal use case for Watson.

There are other use cases out there. Financial services has shown an interest in using it as a wealth advisory tool. A lot of concerns in financial services about regulatory compliance, legal considerations -- do your wealth advisors follow the patterns associated with the particular risk appetite of the customer and then your recommended steps and actions to be taken around portfolio management.

The oversight issues, particularly in Europe, are now becoming so severe that having an electronic guide now is becoming an interesting option for businesses. And frankly anything that involves advisory services where you have N number of combinations, as the combinations grow the complexity grows, the computer becomes an unbelievably important tool to try to get it right the first time.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Got you. Yes, I always joke that Watson is going to put equity sell side research out of business because it can answer all our stock questions. But that said, I mean just the business model quickly. I mean, is this more going to be a subscription model thinking about how folks want to tap into the data or use it on a platform basis?

STEVE MILLS: Well, I mean, certainly there are notions of self-service. You can speak to the system, the system today understands English. We are working on other languages. And obviously you can ask questions, system will provide answers. But the curation of the data, getting the data right is one of the bigger challenges that businesses have.

Data curation -- for all of the buzz we have on big data and analytics and so on and so forth, for those that deal with this every day they know data curation is probably the number one thing they are going to spend their money on. They are going to spend less money on tooling than they will on curation.

And then for these complex problem spaces, what is true? When we do a healthcare project we work with the researchers and physicians on patterns, relationships and truths. And the expertise of the physician becomes an important part of getting the system to where the system understands the truth and is able to statistically and probabilistically calculate out what is likely to be true given the arrival of a new piece of data.

So those kinds of characteristics exist in all of these problem sets. And Watson certainly is well suited to many advisory types of roles. But there are other technology spaces, other use cases that don't necessarily need that kind of [inferencing] capability.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Okay. So maybe let's shift gears and talk about cloud a little bit. I know Amazon was starting to disclose some data there, but I guess my bigger question is, how is IBM set up to beat an AWS or Microsoft or Google you pick your player. What is sort of the differentiation?

STEVE MILLS: Well, a number of things. We have a set of offerings in our portfolio that frankly reflect what others are doing. So many of -- all the major players are doing some things that are similar to each other. Insofar as we have an Infrastructure-as-a-Service type of environment and literally tens of thousands of companies are hosted on the SoftLayer environment. We expanded that from 13 locations now to more than 40 locations around the world.

That is important because in so many places in the world people want to keep the data in country. Germany does not want to move their data anywhere, for example, but that is not unique to Germany. And so, having that infrastructure ability is important from that perspective.

And we do all the same kinds of offerings for storage, networking and compute. We have by-the-hour billing as well as longer-term kinds of contract relationships with customers.

We have a platform as a service environment for application development and there we have done some things quite unique in that Amazon certainly has a lot of tooling and capability, we have all of that and more. Our environment is very heterogeneous and designed to deal with virtually any tool. And by the way, you can bring your own tools, your own capability to bear.

And we announced this year that that platform as a service environment is also available to be installed locally. But many of our customers -- you think of big financial institutions, they worry a lot about where is their data, who is doing what, where.

So they want to keep certain things on premise. So we are providing an on-premise footprint that actually collaborates with the public cloud on our premise footprint. And you can build out your dev ops and agile development-based environment, it is all about an API component-based assembly process.

Then we have a whole set of software as a service offerings, over 100 offerings in our portfolio geared very specifically to software as a service. So those are where you are less concerned about changing and manipulating, you just simply want to get access to the tooling, the capability, the applications in the classical software as a service mode.

So we are doing certainly what others are doing, but our portfolio spreads quite broadly across these many different kinds of offerings. And our ability to deliver on hybrid, which so many larger businesses are interested in.

You are not going to break your business process just because of cloud. You are going to say, wait a minute, I need to run from end to end, I need to enable my order to cash, my straight through processing infrastructure.

And there may be elements that I want to run in a cloud, public, private, whatever term you want to use, protected, open. But I need to have process choreography, I need to have recoverability, I need to have audit ability. And again, those are areas that we are investing in.

We have 100% transparency into our SoftLayer infrastructure, nobody else delivers that, Amazon doesn't do it, Microsoft doesn't do it. You can track every transaction, every change, every access right down to the device level. You can see absolute -- our audit ability is as good as any corporate in-house audit ability for our environment. And again for most large businesses, the regulation and audit ability is a critical differentiator.

So, we are quite enthusiastic about this idea of hybrid cloud shared services, Federated services. And we think this represents one of the bigger opportunities in the world of cloud.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Okay, no, that is good to hear. You sort of touched upon a lot of subjects there. So it reminded me I want to make sure I ask you just this question, again bigger picture. You mentioned SaaS and whatnot, just this concept of [co-opetition] and partnership.

I know partnership was a big theme that IBM talked about at your investor conference. So how is IBM approaching partnership? I know there has been Apple and Twitter and others have been mentioned as partners. I am just curious what has changed, what is the new approach towards partnership here and co-opetition?

STEVE MILLS: Well, first of all we have done this for a very long time. And so, it is not new. But as you -- as we think about where the markets are going, we see this ecosystem dynamic becoming ever more important. And there is some literature and things written about this.

People will talk about platforms and other terms that are used that are indicative of this idea that you establish, if you will, some sort of base technology and then you want to build popularity around that. And as it becomes more popular you get more participation. And so you get this exponential effect taking place as more and more people are participating.

Clearly around an open-based approach a lot of boats can rise, so ours would not be the only one to benefit from these kinds of things. But we certainly would get our benefit from it.

We have been a major driver around things like OpenStack, that was IBM working with Rackspace to bring that out as an open environment the things we did with Pivotal and Cloud Foundry. The myriad of open initiatives that we are engaged in through different types of dot.org entities, those are all part of the what we are doing.

We've moved our power architecture into an OpenPOWER model similar to ARM. So we are now licensing power complete with all the IP and diagrams to build a power processor to anybody who is a member of the OpenPOWER consortium. There are 110 companies now that are members of OpenPOWER.

As a result of that you will see Google here at the end of this year begin to deliver boards into their systems, into their racks that are power based, not just Intel-based.

So that ARM licensing dynamic is something the industry is very familiar with. Every one of the handheld devices in this room is ARM based. And frankly the industry likes that kind of model because it provides freedom of action and the ability to create derivative work. So again, moving to more of a partner driven model.

Clearly you look at our cloud initiative, you look at the SoftLayer environment, we are trying to get more and more independent software vendors to run on that environment. You have to create partner models, we are doing that with SAP and dozens of other independent software vendors.

Apple is all about -- Apple's motivation to do more in the enterprise and our motivation to do a better job of enabling where our customers want to go in the enterprise with mobility. So that partnership has mutual benefit in terms of what it does for us as well as what it does for them.

Twitter, I mean Twitter wants to put their data to work. We have a very big footprint in e-commerce and in marketing analytics. So bringing Twitter data in and, by the way, combining it with other data so there are other data sources. You saw us make an announcement with Facebook.

So again, it is bringing more of that external data in. All of that, again, designed to help the retailer do a better job of figuring out customer preference, loyalty dynamics and so on.

So we are constantly focused on can we build out ecosystems that expand the interest the market has in IBM and our boat will rise. But it is going to rise in conjunction with other boats.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Yes, right, yeah. So you mentioned ecosystems, I know models are changing. So I guess bringing it back to IBM and the business you run on the software side, I know that last year there was obviously a negative surprise there.

So I am curious just how visibility is now in general. I don't know if it is worth going through what happened last year. But how do you approach sort of visibility and budgeting on the software side with respect to the revenue outlook?

STEVE MILLS: So, I mean our business is obviously a big business, $25 billion software business inside of IBM and it has a lot of different component pieces. So to start out with what you are working with, and the good news is we have about 70% of the business which is annuity. It is either monthly license charge, mainframe-based technology, not necessarily something that grows, although when we cycle the systems we usually get a little bit of uptick and then it flattens out and goes down.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Right.

STEVE MILLS: Subscription and support which goes with the install base and we have tens of millions of licenses of our products installed around the world. So that generates a sizable amount of revenue for IBM. But that last 30% comes from transactions. And the transactions take multiple forms.

So the good news is some of our largest clients do very large transactions but they don't do them all the time. So it is wonderful when they do a large transaction, those large transactions give them tremendous flexibility, they are essentially portfolio transactions. And they have the ability to mix and match and choose across the product line.

So they will do one every so many years. I mean typical large deal transactions these days run about three years. Some companies do five years. So not unusual to get three year plus types of transactions. It creates a rather lumpy transaction business, however.

We do a lot of small transactions and we are continuing to spread our resources and partner resources to go wider in the market. And of course Software-as-a-Service, which is growing substantially for IBM, significant double-digit growth even some parts of our portfolio even as much as triple-digit growth.

But we want that to be, because it has an annuity characteristic, an even bigger part of the transaction flow because it will manifest itself in even more predictable annuity stream flow in the future.

So we have got to work all these dynamics. It is what you deal with in any portfolio. Parts of the portfolio such as collaboration are moving pretty rapidly towards SaaS or our traditional notes business along with things like connections and other collaboration technologies in IBM are moving quickly to a SaaS-based market preference.

Application development tools are becoming more in the cloud because of the variability of usage. So you get some of those aspects that you manage through the business.

But we know we are in the right places. We are seeing solid market reaction to things we are doing in newer areas whether it is analytics or security and people still buy traditional middleware. With 35 million servers deployed around the world, there is still a lot of middleware infrastructure that goes into today's IT environments that does get refreshed.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Okay, no, that is helpful. So we've got about 5 minutes left. I've got a couple questions here. Maybe I'll just round it out, Steve. I am not going to hit all these questions obviously. But maybe just a bigger picture question. You have seen a lot of tech waves. You have been at IBM for a long time -- a while let's say.

I mean maybe just talk to us -- we like to sweat a lot of the details and the obvious questions, I am sure you're getting them all the time. But maybe what do you see that maybe we are missing and maybe people don't appreciate from a software perspective or IBM perspective that you would highlight for us?

STEVE MILLS: Well, I think that there is a certain infatuation with every wave that comes along. For those that have been around long enough they can think of the dialogue, the rhetoric and the discussions that occurred with every perceived technology wave that somehow or other the new would eliminate the old. And yet that hasn't really been the case.

Infrastructure is like a city, whether it is Boston or New York or whatever your favorite city is. You see change and change to the skyline, you see improvement. But you also do see a lot of things that are as they were. They haven't changed or maybe they have gotten a new coat of paint and some renovation. Certainly the subway cars in New York City today are air-conditioned, I remember when they were not air-conditioned. And so those kinds of things happen.

So the old doesn't entirely disappear. It is really a matter of how the old transforms itself to do more of what people want to do with it today while still supporting things that they wanted to do before. And that happens with every single wave that we have seen.

Now I mean change is inevitable, so we view this as a journey, not a destination. So it doesn't matter what the period of time is that will be the next new set of things that people will be talking about and will have a change effect. For an IBM that means we need to go where the market is going. It also means we need to leverage what is changing and bring it back to the base.

One of the fastest growing drivers of mainframe MIPS consumption in the industry today is direct connect of mobile devices to mainframes. Most people in this room don't know that if they go do an account look up on their mobile device there is a good chance it is going back into their mainframe environment to actually get that data.

It happens; unless you are in the IT shop you don't pay much attention to it. But if you are in the IT shop you are a little bit startled by how your capacity requirements are going up as a function of mobile device access.

Almost a third of all of the mainframe MIPS deployed in the world today are running Linux. In fact, there are many companies that are running Linux only-based mainframe environments. There are some companies that are running more Linux than traditional z/OS workloads. And so, that thing that is the mainframe, one of the sort of older products that's been around in our industry keeps morphing and transforming and changing.

The new mainframe is a 10 terabyte memory system, able to do in line analytics in conjunction with transaction processing. And to do so economically to where it is questionable whether you ought to be replicating all your data off the mainframe.

So we are constantly adding and adapting different use scenarios to where the market wants to go. And in every case you are looking for ways in which the existing technologies can be taken, if you will, moved forward to the next generation of use scenarios.

So, this perception that somehow or another everything is just going in a direction is just not true. It is a $2 trillion industry. And so there are many directions all at once that the industry is moving in.

I also think that there is a lot of confusion over revenue pools versus profit pools. And revenue is one of the easiest things to find in the tech industry. And profit is one of the hardest. And so, you see a lot of interesting dynamics.

Now if you are one of those companies that is given extraordinary market valuations without necessarily having to deliver profits, well, I suppose why not. I am not part of one of those companies, but if I was I am sure I would be sitting there smiling going this is great.

I'm just going to plow back, plow back, plow back and maybe the day will come when the investors will demand that I deliver a different type of business model, but in the short-term if you let me I will just keep plowing back because there is an endless appetite for spending in the tech industry.

There is always something else you would use your money for. Everybody who works for me has stars in their eyes over the money they could spend if only I would let them. But since Martin Schroeter doesn't let me, I don't let them.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Of course.

STEVE MILLS: Some of us have to deliver return on invested capital every quarter.

TIEN-TSIN HUANG: Yes, well it is good to have some discipline. All right, we should probably stop there, wish we had more time, Steve, but really appreciate hearing your views. Thank you so much for being here. Thanks, Steve.
